[start of motion plan]
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms the end-effector (robot wrist) is positioned near the man's neck, with the robot arm approaching from the left side of the image, close to a bent elbow resting on the table. The neck is a roughly cylindrical, soft tissue object with compliance and some natural resistance due to muscles and skin. The man’s neck is oriented vertical relative to the world frame, and the robot wrist is holding or about to grasp around the neck area. The environment includes a rigid table surface beneath the arm and some loose cables and equipment, but no obstacles interfere with neck contact. The wrist-relative frame location is right at the grasping point on the neck.

The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as such: The red X-axis of the wrist points roughly horizontally to the man’s right (somewhat aligned with the table surface and lateral direction). The green Y-axis roughly points out front, away from the man’s body towards the robot or workspace camera, corresponding to the forward direction in the world. The blue Z-axis points roughly upward, aligned with the vertical direction of the man’s neck in the world frame.

The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to upward/downward motion along the man’s neck length in the world; positive Z motion moves the robot end-effector grasp point upward toward the chin, and negative Z moves downward toward the collarbone.

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object must move both slightly upward and downward by small increments (±0.02 m) to provide thorough massage along the full neck length.

The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to motion laterally across the man’s neck (side to side), left-right in the world frame.

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the object must move side-to-side with small lateral sliding and gentle pressure to rub the muscles, approximately ±0.01 m.

The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to forward and backward motion from the robot base towards/away from the man’s neck (depth axis).

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the object must have small pulsations or gentle pressing in the forward (+Y) direction about 0.01 m and slight backward retraction (-Y) for controlled force application.

To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object must be moved with combined slow, controlled sliding in x and z axes (±0.01 to 0.02 m) and slight pulsating motion in y axis (±0.01 m), covering the neck surface with massage strokes.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert negative and positive alternating lateral sliding forces around 5 N on the neck muscles to simulate massage lateral pressure.

Linear Y-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert positive force approximately 8 N to maintain firm but safe contact pressure against the neck, and minor negative force during retraction phases about 3 N.

Linear Z-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert alternating positive and negative forces of about 4 N to move along the length of the neck, applying pushing and lifting massage strokes.

Angular X-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert small angular torques clockwise and counterclockwise of about 0.5 N-m to implement gentle rotational rubbing around the neck circumference.

Angular Y-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert small angular torque clockwise about 0.3 N-m to tilt the end-effector gently along the neck contour for better contact during strokes.

Angular Z-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert small alternating counterclockwise and clockwise torque about 0.7 N-m to rotate the wrist for circular or twisting massage motions.

Grasping force: The neck tissue is soft and fragile; the grasp must be firm enough to avoid slipping but gentle enough to prevent discomfort or injury. Assuming moderate skin friction coefficient (~0.5) and soft tissue compliance, a grasping force in the range of 12 to 18 N is justified to maintain stable holding with low slip risk and safe pressure on the neck.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Human neck: soft tissue, cylindrical geometry, estimated local mass ~0.5 kg, skin friction coefficient ~0.5, tissue compliant and delicate"

# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Combined gentle vertical sliding ±0.02 m (Z), lateral sliding ±0.01 m (X), and forward-back pulsations ±0.01 m (Y) with slight rotational motions for thorough massage along and around the neck"

# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z]. 
wrist_motion_vector = [0.01, 0.01, 0.02]

# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [5.0, 8.0, 4.0, 0.5, 0.3, 0.7]

# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 15.0

# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 60.0
```

[end of motion plan]

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities.

Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
